speaker: Marco Rubio
vclaim: "Forty percent of the people in this country, illegally, stay with too many visas."
date: stated on July 22, 2015 in an appearance on 'Fox & Friends':
title: Rubio says 40% of illegal immigrants stayed in the U.S. after their visa expired.
text: Mr. Marco Rubio said that although infiltration into the United States was a legitimate problem, the immigration system was so broken that nearly half of all illegal immigrants came to the country through legal channels. "We have porous borders, which means not only the border with Mexico, but 40 percent of the people in this country, illegally, If that's what looks familiar, it's because Rubio said it before -- including during his 2010 Senate election campaign. Previously on Goff... The Bush pocket also mentioned the number. However, is it true that 40 percent of illegal immigrants are overstaying on a visa? It turns out that we often hear this figure because it's the most acceptable estimate, even though it gets a little longer in age. An old problem we didn't hear from Rubio's office when we tried to contact them, but it probably referred to an account made by the Pew Research Centre, an independent "manufacturing tank" that didn't take political positions. In a 2006 report, Pew estimated that "half of all unauthorized migrants currently living in the United States have entered the country legally through a port of entry such as an airport or border crossing where they are subject to inspection by immigration officials." While source data give an estimate ranging from 33 per cent to 50 per cent, the report went halfway and was called 45 per cent. That report was based on a study conducted by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in 1997. While the Immigration and Naturalization Service attempted to ascertain the number of immigrants who arrived in and left the United States, it concluded that 41 per cent of illegal immigrants entered the United States legally in 1996. Robert Warren, a former demographer of the Department of Immigration and Naturalization whose work was part of the 1997 report, told Poletti Fact that migration trends had changed over the years. Since 2008, the number of migrants whose visas exceed the number of migrants who cross the border illegally has generally been lower. The total number of illegal immigrants generally agreed in the United States is now around 11 million, down from a high of 12 million in 2007. On February 1, 2021, Tom Cotton mentioned in an interview with Fox and friends "Many of these arriving immigrants, we have no way of checking their background for either health or security." By Miriam Valverdi, 3 February 2021, but Warren, currently a fellow in the non-partisan immigration studies centre, said the percentage of all excess stays "have been constant over the past 30 years. Most people who crossed the border illegally came from about half a dozen countries, particularly Mexico. Unlicensed migrants from all other countries are almost all stays. In January 2003, the Immigration and Naturalization Service issued an updated report stating that 33 per cent of illegal immigrants in 2000 had entered the country legally. A report issued in 2004 by the General Accounting Office, based on 2000 data, provided estimates of visa overruns ranging from 27 per cent to 31 per cent and 57 per cent. However, no one has really updated these estimates since then, primarily because of the lack of available data from which new conclusions can be drawn, as stated by Mark Rosenblum, Institute of Migration Policy. He said that internal security had developed a methodology for estimating visa violators between air and sea passengers, but he had no formal way of counting people entering the land. A spokesman for the Department of Immigration and Customs assured us that she had not recently published statistics on the number of cases of over-staying. Rosenblum now said that old estimates are the best estimates available. Internal security promised Congress that it would collect new data, as he said, but no results were announced. Until then, there's no really competing research into Rubio's claim. "The short answer is that no reliable estimate has been published since Pio's study," said Rosenblum. The governor Rubio said, "40% of the people in this country, illegally, overstay their visa." These widely cited statistics are an estimate based on research rooted in the 1990s. However, since the federal agencies did not provide new data, there is nothing that analysts can use to provide an updated number. The experts (including the demographics who made the preliminary estimate) told us that although illegal migration trends have changed over the years, 40 per cent of them can still be considered acceptable. We appreciate that Rubio's statement is mostly true.
